Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 213, \u00a7 1.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 213, § 1 and the general jurisdiction of the Middlesex Superior Court over tort claims occurring within Middlesex County.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 3 because the acts and omissions complained of occurred in Middlesex County.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, \u00a7 2A.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, § 2A (statute of limitations for tort actions — personal injury);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 85 (general tort jurisdictional provisions);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 60B.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 60B (as to expert testimony; if necessary);

Doucette v. Friendly Ice Cream Corp., 39.raw_text: Doucette v. Friendly Ice Cream Corp., 391 Mass. 672 (1984)
Doucette v. Friendly Ice Cream Corp., 39.proposition: Doucette v. Friendly Ice Cream Corp., 391 Mass. 672 (1984) (premises liability and notice; illustrative of invitee duties)*
Doucette v. Friendly Ice Cream Corp., 39.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal homicide case (murder, self‑defense, jury issues, conflicts of interest, spousal privilege). It does not involve premises liability, status of entrants (invitee/licensee), or notice of dangerous conditions on land. Therefore it cannot be authority for premises liability or invitee duties, and citing it for that proposition would be inaccurate.
Doucette v. Friendly Ice Cream Corp., 39.relevant_excerpt: On January 10, 1979, two indictments charging murder in the first degree were returned against the defendant, Gregory Szczuka. The victims, Kevin Robinson and Kenneth F. Wescott, had been shot by the defendant in Topsfield on November 8, 1973, and died thereafter. On May 24, 1979, an Essex County jury returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the second degree on each indictment. Szczuka was sentenced to concurrent terms of life imprisonment...

Gannon v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 60 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Gannon v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 60 Mass. App. Ct. 111 (2004)
Gannon v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 60 Mass. Ap.proposition: Gannon v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 60 Mass. App. Ct. 111 (2004) (slip-and-fall/notice issues)*
Gannon v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 60 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case involving child pornography and related assault charges, focusing on sufficiency of evidence regarding the victim’s age and the defendant’s knowledge of that age. It does not involve premises liability, slip-and-fall facts, or notice issues, nor does it discuss any standards for notice in a slip-and-fall context. Therefore, it cannot support a proposition about slip-and-fall/notice issues in Gannon v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 60 Mass. App. Ct. 111 (2004); it appears to be an entirely different “Gannon” case and citation is mismatched.
Gannon v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 60 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant claims there was insufficient evidence that the victim was under the age of eighteen when the defendant took the photographs in question… Whether there was sufficient evidence the defendant knew or possessed sufficient facts that he should have known the victim was under the age of eighteen is another matter… The evidence before us indicates that the victim was between seventeen and eighteen at the time of the offense. However… the evidence does not establish beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant knew or should have known that the victim had not yet reached her eighteenth birthday.”

Albright v. Roche Bros., Inc., 460 Mass..raw_text: Albright v. Roche Bros., Inc., 460 Mass. 523 (2011)
Albright v. Roche Bros., Inc., 460 Mass..proposition: Albright v. Roche Bros., Inc., 460 Mass. 523 (2011) (store liability for owner/employee knowledge and notice)*
Albright v. Roche Bros., Inc., 460 Mass..case_name: Federal National Mortgage Ass'n v. Nunez
Albright v. Roche Bros., Inc., 460 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns the retroactive application and scope of G.L. c. 186A, which restricts post‑foreclosure evictions without just cause. It does not involve premises liability, stores, or rules about an owner’s or employee’s knowledge and notice of dangerous conditions. The proposition misattributes a store‑liability/notice principle to a tenant‑protection/retroactivity decision, so the citation does not support the claimed point.
Albright v. Roche Bros., Inc., 460 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "We conclude that the provision of the act that prevents eviction without just cause is properly applied to protect all residential tenants on foreclosed properties who, on or after August 7, 2010, had yet to vacate or be removed from the premises by an eviction, even where the owner purchased the property before the act’s effective date and initiated a summary process action before that date."

Mero v. Stop & Shop Cos., 402 Mass. 327.proposition: Mero v. Stop & Shop Cos., 402 Mass. 327 (1988) (notice and foreseeability in slip-and-fall cases)*
Mero v. Stop & Shop Cos., 402 Mass. 327.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Mero v. Stop & Shop Cos., 402 Mass. 327 (1988); it is a criminal case involving Commonwealth v. Lapointe, dealing with homicide, self-defense, evidentiary issues, and jury instructions. It does not address slip-and-fall liability, premises liability, or the doctrines of notice and foreseeability in that context. Therefore, this opinion cannot support a proposition about notice and foreseeability in slip-and-fall cases.
Mero v. Stop & Shop Cos., 402 Mass. 327.relevant_excerpt: The opinion discusses issues such as self-defense, evidence of the victim’s reputation, post-traumatic stress disorder, jury instructions, prosecutorial misconduct, and sentencing, but contains no discussion of premises liability, slip-and-fall accidents, or notice/foreseeability standards for property owners.

Quigley v. Northeast Utilities, 403 Mass.proposition: Quigley v. Northeast Utilities, 403 Mass. 408 (1988) (premises duty principles)*
Quigley v. Northeast Utilities, 403 Mass.case_name: Markel Service Insurance Agency, Inc. v. Tifco, Inc.
Quigley v. Northeast Utilities, 403 Mass.support_reasoning: This case concerns allocation of loss between an insurance general agent and a premium finance company, construing third‑party‑beneficiary contract rights and Massachusetts insurance statute G.L. c. 175, § 169. It does not involve premises liability, landowner duties, or any premises‑duty principles. Citing this decision for a premises‑duty proposition would therefore be inaccurate and out of context.
Quigley v. Northeast Utilities, 403 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "Tifco maintains, however, that the intended beneficiary rule does not apply because its payment to Ryan constituted payment to Markel under G. L. c. 175, § 169 (1986 ed.). … Thus we conclude that Tifco’s payment to Ryan constituted payment to the insurer under G. L. c. 175, § 169."

MacGregor v. Boston & Maine R.R., 374 Ma.raw_text: MacGregor v. Boston & Maine R.R., 374 Mass. 225 (1978)
MacGregor v. Boston & Maine R.R., 374 Ma.proposition: MacGregor v. Boston & Maine R.R., 374 Mass. 225 (1978) (duty and reasonable care standards)*
MacGregor v. Boston & Maine R.R., 374 Ma.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurrence that focuses on whether the case should continue to be governed by the traditional 'hidden defect' rule for landowner liability and criticizes the majority’s decision to abrogate that rule in this particular case. It does not itself articulate or redefine a general duty or reasonable care standard; it instead assumes the existing hidden-defect framework and argues the case can be resolved within it. Thus, as quoted, it does not function as clear authority for a general proposition about duty and reasonable care standards.
MacGregor v. Boston & Maine R.R., 374 Ma.relevant_excerpt: This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. The jury returned a substantial verdict for the plaintiff. The defendant appealed, contending that there was insufficient evidence to support the verdict. The Appeals Court agreed, reversed the judgment and vacated the verdict. On the plaintiff’s appeal therefrom this court is ordering that the verdict and judgment for the plaintiff be reinstated, holding that the evidence was sufficient to support the verdict.

Dwyer v. Jordan Marsh Co., 371 Mass. 525.raw_text: Dwyer v. Jordan Marsh Co., 371 Mass. 525 (1976)
Dwyer v. Jordan Marsh Co., 371 Mass. 525.proposition: Dwyer v. Jordan Marsh Co., 371 Mass. 525 (1976) (employer/store duty to customers)*
Dwyer v. Jordan Marsh Co., 371 Mass. 525.support_reasoning: This is a criminal manslaughter/abortion case against a physician; it does not concern an employer or store, nor does it analyze any duty owed by a store or employer to customers. The opinion focuses on abortion law, viability, manslaughter standards, and evidentiary sufficiency, so it cannot serve as authority for a proposition about an employer/store duty to customers.
Dwyer v. Jordan Marsh Co., 371 Mass. 525.relevant_excerpt: "Manslaughter assumes that the victim was a live and independent person. This is well understood, and the judge so charged. Destruction of a fetus in utero is not a manslaughter.... [T]he essential proposition emerges that the defendant on this record had no evil frame of mind, was actuated by no criminal purpose, and committed no wanton or reckless acts in carrying out the medical procedures on October 3, 1973."

Puffer v. Allworth, 390 Mass. 83 (1983).proposition: Puffer v. Allworth, 390 Mass. 83 (1983) (causation and proximate cause in negligence)*
Puffer v. Allworth, 390 Mass. 83 (1983).support_reasoning: The provided text is a brief dissenting opinion addressing only the admissibility and prejudicial effect of a composite sketch in a criminal trial. It does not discuss negligence, causation, or proximate cause, nor does it establish any rule on those topics. Therefore, it cannot properly be cited as authority for a proposition about causation and proximate cause in negligence.
Puffer v. Allworth, 390 Mass. 83 (1983).relevant_excerpt: Because I believe that admission of the composite was prejudicial error, I would reverse the conviction and remand for a new trial.

Sweeny v. St. John's Prep School, 442 Ma.raw_text: Sweeny v. St. John's Prep School, 442 Mass. 123 (2004)
Sweeny v. St. John's Prep School, 442 Ma.proposition: Sweeny v. St. John's Prep School, 442 Mass. 123 (2004) (notice and duty context)*
Sweeny v. St. John's Prep School, 442 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is about the definition of “secondary school” under the Massachusetts school‑zone statute and the irrelevance of Department of Education regulations in that context. It does not analyze notice, duty, or any tort-like obligations; its brief mention of knowledge (“[l]ack of knowledge of school boundaries shall not be a defense”) is statutory interpretation, not a broader notice/duty doctrine. Citing this case generally for a “notice and duty context” proposition would be misleading unless the proposition is narrowly about knowledge under G.L. c. 94C, § 32J, which the citation here does not specify.
Sweeny v. St. John's Prep School, 442 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Moreover, since the enactment of the school zone statute, see St. 1989, c. 227, § 2, the Legislature has expanded the zone of safety to include other places where children would likely be present… Decisional law has determined that it matters not whether the drug dealer has knowledge of the location and existence of a qualifying school… a violation of the school zone statute ‘has nothing to do with the nature of the school[].’”
